data.message:
The American Legion's women veterans survey ends Sept. 18. Answers will be shared with Congress and the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs.
American Women veterans can take the survey at the link below.
American Legion is interested in helping FEMALE Veterans? Bullshit. I don't believe that for one minute. They must need more women in their Auxiliary. They don't consider us veterans.

I have recently quit my local American Legion in this Oregon coastal town. Yes, I did take this survey, but the reason I quit the legion was because it will take an act of congress (yes, lower case) to change the Legion and I am too old to wait around for inclusion. I believe it does not serve women or the younger veterans. Women are not welcome in this old boys network. I will find someplace else to volunteer my time. I have PTSD from MST and support all the women and men suffering from this problem.

Sorry but AL isnt all that. I had active duty females part of LIMDU they sent over there in Texas to get help for VA claims...and had them coming to me later on saying they told them they where auxiliary force..
Survey really needs to have a space for written comments. Not all of the possible chooses for each answer was adequate and it would have been nice to state that in my own words.
done

Actually, just read all the questions and any women that did not served in these combat zones do not count.  Cold War Veterans (Women)  Need to be recognized!  Those of us that served in the Navy on Ships and Deployed?  Where is our support?  These questions must be a joke?
Edie, have you seen this
I don't see a link to take this survey.
Again Peace Time Veterans that deployed for months on end in the US Navy.  NOT RECOGNIZED!
Ladies- the survey takes only a few minutes.  If it applies, take it.

am single Army man and looking for a soul mate .. am a new member on here just joined and looking for the right woman in my life . Am 40years old 5-4 ft tall, 128 lbs  and also never married.I am Caring, Faithful, Loyal,Truthful, Loving,  Generous, Goals Achiever,Honest, Spiritual oriented,Future ,driven, confidential, Understands the ups and downs of life,   Committed to relationship, Reader, Visionary, Conservative,Passionate, Romantic,.
"For the first time, women hold all of the top student leadership positions at Texas A&M!"
My retired Lt Col self applauds each and every one of you; it is women like you who got us to where WE are today! Keep on keeping on!! Bravo, well done.
Well my granddaughters tell me that nana the boss? What should I do.
Susie Ayala how cool is this
Such pretty leaders........waytago.
Go ladies!
Carpe Diem!üòä‚ù§
fantastic!!
üá∫üá∏ We Salute Them All ! üá∫üá∏
Wow. Just wow.
Awesome!üòÄ
Awesome
Good for them.
Good
OUTSTANDING
Karoline Lewis
Way to go.  Looking good oughta be in Hollywood.
John Richie

am single Army man and looking for a soul mate .. am a new member on here just joined and looking for the right woman in my life . Am 40years old 5-4 ft tall, 128 lbs  and also never married.I am Caring, Faithful, Loyal,Truthful, Loving,  Generous, Goals Achiever,Honest, Spiritual oriented,Future ,driven, confidential, Understands the ups and downs of life,   Committed to relationship, Reader, Visionary, Conservative,Passionate, Romantic,.

Welcome to the great brotherhood temple of illuminati society. Do you want to be rich and famous? Do you need power to control the world? Do you want power to make your business be the best and international or do you need continues promotion. Come today join us in our great brotherhood temple of illuminati. Our email is: greatbrotherhoodilluminati777@gmail.com  Also call or WhatsApp us on +2348050693178

Dear U.S. Marine Corps,

We think you forgot something.

Love,
American Women Veterans

In college we had to write a paper about our "most educational experience."  In my paper I wrote a line that said, "I have always wondered what it would be like for me and other women like me if the Marine Corps had been looking for a 'Few Good Women' too."  Some things never change...
Semper Fi women Marines!! You Rock!!! From former female SSgt, Marine wife and Marine mom of 2!!

As an old Marine, I don't like to be critical but this is a disappointment. Not only have the Women Marines been ignored, there is little "energy" in this film.  Facts, yes.  Excitement, or energy, no.

Sadly, no matter how fast you run (even if you run faster than the males), or how good you shoot, there remains this stigma that seems to linger on in the Corps. At my duty-station, the first words out of my Gunny's mouth were, "I don't believe women should be in the Marine Corps." That motivated me to push myself harder each and every day, to do my best. I never asked for any help, or complained to BAS as much as the males did; however, there comes a time when you realize boundaries have been crossed way past all the harassment and put-downs. All those times I didn't say anything, unfortunately, backfired. It was until years later that I have come to realize that maybe Gunny was right.
We in the business world don't have to endure the physical training and actual combat, but we certainly understand the rest. God bless you and all the women in our armed forces!
Yep, I was thinking the same thing.  Some things never change.

I agree. Fire the person who made this video. It's the subliminal message to every female marine that they are not worthy of being included in this video. When are the services going to recognize that our diversity is what makes us each unique and together we are stronger. Be inclusive... From an Army retired Master Sergeant.
My cousins daughter is a Marine, I am so very proud of her.
I think the USMC is missing the boat. Keep trucking ladies!
Hey nice video but you never showed the female marine. What's up with that Skippy.
that's a very powerful message but where are the women?
Dad was navy his uncles army & marine my -first husband died 1969 a. Green Bara w honors let go
not surprising.

Well the speaker did successfully speak for nearly 3 minutes without using the pronoun "he" so that was a good start.  The video needs to be redone though to include woman...WTF, I find it hard to believe that none of the video producers or editors didn't notice the lack of women Marines in their film.  We are everywhere...they had to go through great pains to exclude the women Marines from this film.
God bless all marines , men and women !!
Still in the year 2016!!  I thought it was bad in 1978. I am a Marine.  I earned it. And no one can take it away.  Semper Fi, all Marines.
yes don't forget us!
What, no women in the Marines?
Propaganda  bullshit
You do have to win. (RET) CPT Janie Chatham USA
They always leave the women out
Thank you all
No shit.

Not to sound anti-feminist  buuuuut: instead of whining and bitching on social media why don't those who have issue with the video do something about it. Why should we be taken seriously if we play the victim over a freaking video?!
All.   Our military R bezt

ICYMI: "At Fort Hood, III Armored Corps hosted an event to celebrate Women‚Äôs Equality Day on Aug. 26 at Club Hood.

The event provided an open forum and question-and-answer session with a panel of three female trailblazers for the Army to address current and future directions that will steadily improve equality for women in the ranks.

Brig. Gen. Maria Barrett, the deputy commanding general of the Joint Force Headquarters-Cyber, United States Army Cyber Command was the keynote speaker.

The other panel members consisted of Command Sgt. Maj. Jill Crosby, the command sergeant major of the Sustainment Brigade, 1st Cavalry Division, and retired Chief Warrant Officer 5 Jeanne Pace, former 1st Cav. Div. Band commander."
Hooah!!!
üá∫üá∏ We Salute American Women Veterans ! üá∫üá∏
Only took how long? Am happy it finally happened!
Finally
Nice
I salute you ladies

"It took a year and a half after her death in 2015 for the Army to formally recognize what Elaine D. Harmon had known most of her life: That the service of female pilots in World War II equaled that of the men who fought.

On Wednesday, in a quiet corner of Arlington National Cemetery, the Army made its recognition permanent, allowing Mrs. Harmon‚Äôs remains to be laid to rest at last with full military honors alongside her fellow veterans.

Mrs. Harmon, who died in April 2015 at age 95, had been a member of the Women Airforce Service Pilots, or WASPs, a first-of-its-kind Army unit made up of women who flew planes and trained men to do the same during World War II."
It's a slap in the face to those brave women for it to have taken this long for her to be buried in ANC. Glad she was finally laid to rest where she deserved.

We women have had to fight for our rights forever. We may have progressed as a society but there is still a struggle to be on a level playing field with men. Although if I had my chance to be either sex, I'd always want to be a woman. We have strength, resilience, deep compassion, profound wisdom and so much more. Not to denigrate men but there it is so
Face It men!

May all these women be blessed whether in the hereafter or still among us. Ironically, while debate raged in the US on the role of these women, the Soviet Union (our ally against Germany in WW2) had thousands of women pilots and aircrew serving in combat billets in the Red Air Force. They flew night and dive bombers, ground - support attack aircraft, and fighters (two female fighter pilots became the only female "aces" in history so far.). Yet political and military men in this country couldn't handle the idea of US women doing the same.

the women who served in WWII were called "auxiliary" and did not get any of the benefits, honors, or medals of the male military.  Women pilots were used to deliver supplies, etc in the battlefield.  If a women pilot died on the battlefield, their coffin was not draped with a flag, they were not given purple heart or any award, and they could not be buried in a military cemetary.
I saw a program about these ladies on PBS a couple of months ago. Wish they would air it again, it was very good. Most people don't know anything about these brave women.
WAY TO LONG!  Do people know that when they died on active service, they were put in a pines box and shipped home and the family paid for it.

Can anyone shed light on what held this up for so long? I am fairly certain that she was a civilian but my basic instrument flight trainer was a woman, and a number of the air traffic controllers is that guided me during flight school where women. Their voices were easier to understand in a noisy cockpit and since all of us we're barely out of puberty, we paid more attention
Rest in peace and thank you for your service for our great nation and for continuing after the war, ensuring those great patriotic women get the benefits they deserve.
A proper salute. I'm grateful for your service. Rest in peace and soar high.
A humble salute to one great lady and all those who fought on her behalf. Godspeed flying the heavens.
It is about time. I am a proud Navy veteran. Thanks for your service.
...yes... they were important... many women were... in many ways... recognition is late in coming... simply be grateful that it finally came...

Well it's about Effin time, their country,and the world called, and these women served, with honor and integrity in their countries uniform, and I'm sure swore the same oath. Should have been a slam dunk years ago
As a a history teacher I always include the women who contributed and put their lives on the line - from the American Revolution to the present.

Awesome!!!
Ladies if we can do this! We can change the world!!!
Was glad to hear this long time coming I wonder if she had been buried somewhere else first!!!
It's not a year and a half.  It's a lifetime!  Her service was in WW2.  Shameful of the US Govt.  These women were heroes, but apparently having a vagina made you not eligible for recognition.
It shouldn't haven't taken this long...

Yes!  She did more than her part.  I read a book about them and how they were learning to fly the aircraft and learning faster than most of their male counterparts... to say they did not serve is a slap in the face.  They paved the way for women like me to serve.
History preserved. At long last, well done.

from.name: Arizona Chapter, Paralyzed Veterans of America

data.message: May she finally RIP
Finally
I am glad she is at peace now .
RIP! Thank You!
Wonderful

American Women Veterans is proud to host a #SuicidePrevention for #WomenVets Facebook chat w/ VA experts. Tune in right here on Sept 16 @ 2PM EST to learn about programs available through the VA and to get *your* questions answered by the experts.

Please share this link meet us back here next Friday!

www.explore.va.gov/events #exploreVA

I have to say that as a woman veteran in FL right now because of the pain I am in on a daily basis, and the lack of timeliness to get care (even through the Choice Card Program) these secondary authorizations are HORRIBLE. I had a mental meltdown yesterday. All I want is to get the care I need so the pain will be tolerable, and I can be "normal." But waiting a month to get a secondary authorization or a referral to go through is disheartening, and I can see why the suicide rate is high, because i felt totally defeated yesterday. Thank Goodness I have a great support system that helped me to see that it will all work out in the end.
Why am I not finding a link to this event?
How does one tune in?
Please, please, please join in the program. I care about our Women Veterans.

May 7, 2013 trump tweeted "26,000 unreported sexual assults (he misspelled this word) in the military -only 238 convictions. What did these geniuses expect when they put men & women together?" ....he stood by his statement on TV tonight. As a veteran (Army Nurse) and victim, I hear this national leader saying it was our fault.

Trump did say something to the effect of why aren't they prosecuted for the assaults? 1976 - co-ed barracks at Osan. No assaults. Respecting each other was the rule and it worked. We need to convict both males and females who assault - it's not a only a sexual thing - it's power and control. As a USAF Law Enforcement K-9 drug dog handler and registered nurse, I see this as a problem because of respect and conviction of the guilty.
The best thing I have ever done for my physical + mental health was choose not to ever use the VA Health Care system, ever again.

After waiting since 2012 for my claim to be addressed, the VA denied my claim- but never informed me of it. I had no idea and continued to wait. Someone in an office somewhere called me and notified me that the next day would end my ability to appeal- and they told me they we calling because they felt it was wrong. I asked why my claim was denied in the first place?! They told me because I didn't show up to appointments... Appointments they never notified me of, and immediately denied the claim. They didn't try and reschedule or anything. The VA had my address and phone number. I made sure it was all updated. It was a deliberate attempt to deny my claim.
I have a claim for MST. There was a rape kit performed, CID investigated and I was granted a compassionate reassignment back stateside (stationed in Germany). I've asked repeatedly what exactly the appointments are for, given I've proven that the events happened already. The response was "to ensure that it has actually had an impact on you" and that "there are some veterans who have had much worse happen, it's not like you lost a limb".
THAT is what the VA does to veterans, especially female veterans. We aren't treated the same while serving, and we definitely won't be treated fairly when we are out. How many female veterans are awaiting recognition for MST cases? How many have to prove that being raped "truly affected them"? How many are being told that the dramatic change in the course of their lives, their nightmares and their fear- isn't as bad as losing a limb? How many of these women are mothers, trying to keep their pain hidden in order to keep it from their children? How many of these women are unable to go back to school, working minimum wage jobs because of the problems with social injustice for women, especially those with children?
Why is it that after I waited until 2012, had to quickly file an appeal for a claim I didn't know was denied, and finally got an appointment that I attended- I was quoted with having to wait 8 MORE YEARS for an answer. That answer- is just the VA saying "yes it happened, and yeah we think it probably affected you for life". Why is it that I was offered a "cure for PTSD" at my last mental health appointment?! BECAUSE THE VA DOESN'T WANT TO APPROVE CLAIMS. AND THE VA DOESN'T THINK THAT RAPE IS TRAUMATIC.
Am I the only one to question that the date on the email I received was Wed, Sept 16? Now I see on here that it's Friday. Thanks.

I wanted to add that Mr Trump stated that the VA was to blame for the veteran suicide issue and I want to say that Leavenworth VA is wonderful for women vets and I wouldn't be here today if it wasn't for them.
Been there too Amanda. No fun, that's for sure. I'm a woman vet in PA.

When I was young I felt like taking my life when things were I thought too hard. And I tried, a few times, I thought if I could not give my kids a good home, maybe if I died some one would take them and give them a better home than I could provide. I was left a lot and divorced and then I lost my home. Being it was based on two checks instead of one. I prayed for my daughter who was at that time living with her dad, because I thought maybe I was too hard on her and I thought maybe she would be happier.. God said he wold give me the promise of Isiah which was strange because I only read the New Testament because the Old Testament seemed to hard at the time, Well I opened my Bible at right at the beginning was Isiah 40:7 The grass withers and the flower fades but the word of God will be for ever. So the thing you and I can count on is the Word of God. and guess what I discovered tough times don't last tough people with Christ Spirit and Truth will last. He will help you threw the toughest storms.

It would help to get to the root cause of why the military is causing so many service members and Veteran's to be suicidal and die by suicide. Each military branch needs to just look inward. Unchecked Workplace Bullying,  Sexual Harassment, Sexual Assault, and the resulting retaliation is responsible for a large percentage of this Crisis.
Please share this with all your friends. Thank you.
Good work. A very useful program.
New FB Group: MARINE MST SURVIVORS

"As of January 1, all combat roles in the U.S. military have been open to women. But that doesn't mean women soldiers are actually being treated the same way as men.

For a study published in Sex Roles, University of Kansas researchers interviewed male and female military personnel about their views on gender and the treatment they've received, and it's clear that while policies may have changed, the male-centered culture within the military hasn't.

The researchers also found that men were "policing the boundaries of gender in the military context," and since men still hold most of the leadership positions, they had the opportunity to reinforce gender inequality. For example, women were frequently being left out of the Special Forces, since men were usually the ones deciding who to accept."

We can prove ourselves all day long but in the end it doesn't change the way males feelüòû I deployed with an infantry unit in 2009, did the same thing as all the guys and gained little respect. There are pansy men & women and there are badass strong men & women in the military! Trust me I've seen it all. But I'm proud of all my sisters who have accomplished so much to prove that women can handle combat!

Yup sounds about right... They're even sending us to combat units and STRONGLY encouraging us to reclass to combat jobs when they haven't even fixed the Gender issues we've faced and continue to face on a day to day basis üò°. Sorry guys but I'll pass...
Work twice as hard for half the respect and still get told we have it easy? I'm absolutely shocked that things haven't really changed in the decade since I got out. üòí

The public, and especially current leaders, often do not want to face reality or facts. The majority of females want no part of combat arms jobs. They know about the physiological differences and capabilities between men and women, despite the current leaders, feminists and politicians rhetoric that females can do anything males can do. Women are smart enough to anticipate the problems, spoken and unspoken, that are being ignored for the sake of political correctness. And most female NCOs know too much about the life and requirements of combat arms jobs to volunteer for combat arms MOS reclassification. They have already met with success in their current MOS and would run the risk of ruining their careers by switching to a combat arms job where they would be at a huge disadvantage in physical capabilities (strength, endurance, weight bearing differences, etc. of women compared to the testosterone fueled physiological abilities of males), and in years of MOS experience they missed out on, and in credibility with any combat arms males in the units they would be assigned to. Do not expect many clear thinking female soldiers and/or NCOs in their right minds to volunteer for all that.

I was a part of a few different types of units when I served. I worked in General staff, Aviation, and then the Infantry. I didn't really feel the sexisum that much until I served in the support company for the Infantry Battalion. We where treated like second class citizens even though we did everything for them. We brought them food, ammo, transportation, and hauled them and their shit around everywhere. When the announcement was made that women would be allowee into combat MOS's I watched a 1SG drop the SSG that told him about it because he was so pissed. The attitude comes from the top down in these combat MOS's. I fear that things will not change anytime soon. It did not get better when I was reasigned to a line company right before I left the service. I know that the new command was trying to look like they where integrating women into Infantry units, but I worked there and I felt like a secretary.

Newsflash. The treatment we are discussing here is everywhere, not just the Army, and it isn't going away. It does women no good to cry "unfair". Just keep working hard and the world will change by your actions, not your crying.

This is so sad, I would like to say I am surprised but I am not. There are only TWO types of people in this world- Men and Women- and they are discriminating against over half of the worlds population.

As a male I had to change my way of thinking. I served my country for twenty years in the U.S. Navy. I retired a Boatswains Mate 1ST Class (E-6). I was in command of male and female sailors. Most of the women at the commands I served in, were very professional and hard working. The male and females have had disciplinary issues but were treated fairly.
Hang on military women,......they can not do this forever...change is so slow, but it is happening
I think that women in combat would work just fine. Women with PMS, armed and pissed off.
I guess that I was simply oblivious or just old school lucky... My unit rocked. I was never less than one of the guys.
Give it a few more hundred years.
The last 30 years has changed nothing.  I fought the battle for 10.5 years as a Hull maintenance Technician in the US Navy.
Hope L. Russell

"Honor Flight Columbus has organized the first all-women veterans' trip to Washington D.C. The group is scheduled to depart Columbus Sept. 10.

Honor Flight is an organization that provides trips to the nation's capital at no cost to veterans of World War II, the Korean and Vietnam wars. During each trip to Washington, veterans have the chance to visit their respective war memorials. Bill Richards, director emeritus of Honor Flight Columbus, said the Columbus chapter borrowed the idea from Honor Flight Tri-State in Cincinnati.

'Hosting a flight just for women veterans is a great opportunity to give them the honor they are due for their service,' Richards said. He noted that many women who served in the military during World War II, Korea and Vietnam did not always receive respect from their male counterparts. Additionally, the military of that era was not accommodating to women, with many being issued men's boots and uniforms."

Actually, the FIRST all-female Honor Flight was September 22, 2015 when Honor Flight Tri-State (Cinnicitti Ohio) brought it into DCA. This one, I believe, is the first for the Columbus Hub but not the first ever. I was one of the greeters at Reagan when they came in.
Are they visiting the Women's Memorial at Arlington? My mother was a WAVE during WWll, I sponsored her so generations of our family could visit and be proud.

So very good to see their sevice being recognized! Thank you to all the women who have helped shape this great nation!!

On a separate note many a woman well up into the 90's and beyond can tell you that their clothing issued to them was still male. I was in the Navy my dungarees and boondockers (we all had to wear 2 or 3 pairs of socks just to keep them on) were "unisex"  definitely fit for a male. My neice proudly serves today as a SAR and I can tell you her uniforms fits her properly.
This is fantastic.  I've been trying to get to the Womens Memorial,  so close to me but yet unable to make it.  Vietnam Era Veteran, WAC
...good for Ohio... have a pleasant Walk down Memory Lane, ladies... be safe and enjoy...
Ms. Eddie Jo Bazor here is a flight of just women going from Ohio!
Thanx to all you wonderful gals who served, and helped protect our country......we owe you.
Enjoy the trip and on your return share your experience and encourage others to go on future flights!
Can other female veterans go, that were not active duty during the war times? Thank you for reply!
Thanks for sharing our first female flight. We are very excited about it here in the Columbus area.
Aout time...
What a great thing to do
Enjoy!
Thank you for your service and enjoy your trip- you deserve It!
God Bless them
Wish it would come to Colimbus Ga.
PEACE AND HONOR
It departs from Columbus on Sept. 10.
Glad to ses this happening the women served also!!!
This is fantastic!  Sure wish every OGHF hub would, at least, try to put something like this together.  Have a ball ladies....you so deserve it!
Fantastic.
OK
Love this gesture, wish I could join you!
Mindy Bernhardt, FYI

"The tipping point of the gender equality struggle might have been the Admirals' Panel at Tailhook '91, attended by more than 2,000 and featuring the leaders of naval aviation ‚Äî eight admirals and one Marine Corps. A female aviator asked the head of naval aviation, "When will women be allowed to fly in combat?" Jeers filled the auditorium.

Vice Adm. Richard Dunleavy answered, "If Congress directs the secretary of the Navy to allow women to fly combat aircraft, the Navy will comply."

Judging by noise that followed, that didn't sit well with the audience. A male junior officer told the admiral, "Your answer was not what the vast majority of naval aviators expected or wanted." Combat, he said, was "a male-only domain." He took his seat, to thunderous applause.

When the noise finally subsided, the admiral repeated his initial response."

As a Naval Aviator (Commander, Pilot,Retired), and proud member of the Tailhook Committee that year and many others, before fingers are once again pointed, ask me! I was the VIP Coordinator for the Reunion, and much of the media information was inaccurate, and falsely reported. Do not believe everything you read in the press, or released by the DOD.

I just wish I had a nickel for every time I had to sign that damn affidavit that I wasn't at Tailhook and no one working for me was there (I was with the P-3 community then, and we weren't cool enough to rate an invitation!) - or that I took heat from male colleagues for happening to be female in the five or ten years that followed. Whatever the intent of the Tailhook Committee, the aviators who attended Tailhook '91, or the investigators from NCIS and IG, the impact truly sucked. For a long time. I'm genuinely curious about your perspective, Elizabeth.
This is also what brought harassment and rape to light. Just for the military to cover it up again.
HA, they laughed when I asked "When will women be allowed to fly?" That was 1952

"Salem County Freeholders and Veterans Administrator recognized Beatrice Coleman as the county‚Äôs oldest Female War Veteran.

Beatrice served in the US Army Woman‚Äôs Army Corp. (WAC) during WWII in 1943-1945 as S/N-A805 912 T/F. Ms. Coleman was formally honored and presented a Board of Chosen Freeholders Certificate. The 94 year old Woodstown resident regularly attends church at Morning Start Baptist Church.

Director Julie Acton stated, ‚ÄúEvery year it is a great honor to present these certificates to our Oldest Armed Forces Veteran‚Äôs. We want our veterans to know we are grateful for their service, and it is particularly special to have the opportunity to honor someone who served 73 years ago in World War II. Every individual has a story and I am glad we were able to honor Mrs. Coleman for heroism in our country‚Äôs history.‚Äù'
God Bless all our Vets. Never forget their service or sacrifice.
Beatrice, we thank you for your service to our country.
Thank you my fellow Veteran for your service ma'am.
Thank you for your service!!
Thank you for your service.
Beatrice, thanks for paving the way for women like me to follow...
...as she should be... it is easy to forget that womn, too... did their part...
Thank you Beatrice Coleman, for your devotion and sacrifice for this great country!! Blessings!!

So proud of all vets. For years after serving in the Air Force I didn't feel people understood that EVERY female  vet enlisted as a choice.  So proud to be a Vietnam Era vet. Proud of my brave predecessors. Thanks to ALL vets,!
Thanks for your service ladies
thanks for your service.
Thank you maam!!!
oooorah Coleman!
Thank Beatrice.
THANKS FOR YOUR SERVICA YOUNG Lady Beauty Vintage

"Manpower officials have modified decade-old rules that offer permanent limited duty status to qualified Marines. Under the new Expanded Permanent Limited Duty Status policy, Marines approved for retention can re-enlist for 48 months at a time, and continue to do so without having to face more retention boards."
It's about time!
Disabled doesn't mean useless!!!  <3

Dear Fellow Patriot,

Please know you have the full and unqualified support of Wake Up and Reclaim America.

We have ‚ÄúLIKED‚Äù you and ‚ÄúSHARED‚Äù you on our page.

Good luck in your continued efforts!

Sincerely,

Doug Underwood
Founder, Wake Up and Reclaim America

https://www.facebook.com/WakeUpAndReclaimAmerica/

"Two events in September will give special attention to local veterans.

The third annual Central Valley Women Veterans Stand Up event is scheduled for 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. Sept. 19. The 25th Central Valley Veterans Stand Down event is planned for Sept. 21-23 from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.

Both events will take place at The Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 8900, 3585 N. Blythe Ave., Fresno.  A free day at the spa is also on the to-do list.

The Stand Down event will give veterans access to community resources, haircuts, hot meals, clothing and educational and employment opportunities."
Let's hope the jobs you're having are actually good paying career oriented jobs and not the bullshit work for Amazon Warehouse minimum wage jobs or other menial labor jobs.

I work for the state of Ohio and I'd like to spread awareness on another event! Please spread the word to anyone who might be interested! Join Ohio Department of Natural Resources Oct. 1 at Maumee Bay State Park in Oregon for G.I. Go, a free program focuses on creating a network of service members, both past and present, which emphasizes community, physical well-being and education on opportunities and benefits available to these groups.

Explore and revitalize one of Ohio‚Äôs 74 state parks with a service project, connect with state resources and have fun with the family doing featured programs including archery, fishing and field-dressing.

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/gi-go-tickets-27488560023?aff=mcivte
üá∫üá∏ We Salute Our American Women Veterans !üá∫üá∏

"Build resilience, heal wounds, and manage stress better
This course empowers women service members and veterans with skills-based knowledge that can be used to increase resilience and create wellness after difficult life experiences. Upon completing this course, veterans will ultimately be able to modify their responses to stressful situations, both past and present, and form stronger, healthier narratives for their futures."
This course is free to all women military veterans.
http://womenwarriors.ucsf.edu/

I think female Veterans would be more happy and able to relieve stress if they could find affordable housing, get good paying jobs that uses their many skills that aren't the low-paying scut jobs companies in the area hand out to us to get their tax break and not be hit or hassled by male Veterans  everytime they walk into a VA Hospital, and could actually get good healthcare from the VA.   But what do I know?
I work at a VA and I don't see women being harassed by male veterans
I have PTSD and I'm a Gulf War Veteran. I'm interested in the Course but I'm not sure I can right now.

"You are warmly invited to apply to participate in our 5th annual Women‚Äôs Practice Period (WPP) beginning September 30 and ending January 7, 2017. There is no cost to participate.

This is an opportunity to:
-Integrate meditation and mindfulness practices more deeply into your daily life
-Deepen what you have learned and experienced at Veteran's PATH retreats or one-day events
-Continue to build a sense of community and support with other women veterans
-Be able to rely on mindfulness practices to be more present for challenging situations in your life

We encourage you to register as soon as possible because we only have 16 slots available."

So yet another bullshit program that does nothing to help Women Veterans get a Career Oriented Job, find Affordable Housing or better healthcare at the VA.  Somebody must have needed something to spend that grant money on so you could be sure to get it for next year.
How lovely is that?!?!?  Wish I'd known about it - hoping I can be of service to this group, anytime!!
Your message states until January.You may want to correct. Thanks.

"As the Army continues to integrate women into combat arms jobs, the 75th Ranger Regiment has seen its first female soldier attempt to join its ranks.

The staff sergeant attended the 75th Ranger Regiment‚Äôs Ranger Assessment and Selection Program 2 in June, officials said.

RASP 2 is designed for soldiers in the rank of staff sergeant and above and all officers volunteering for assignment to the elite regiment.

‚ÄúThe female soldier did not meet performance objectives required for assignment to the 75th Ranger Regiment,‚Äù said Lt. Col. Robert Bockholt, a spokesman for U.S. Army Special Operations Command. ‚ÄúThe female soldier has been afforded the opportunity to reapply for RASP 2 beginning December 2016.‚Äù'
I know her! They gave her very little notice before sending her to RASP2... Sitting on her packet before deciding to send her. She will kick ass at the next one :)
If she qualifies great, but don't change the qualification . I knew a few females in the army that would have had no trouble with carrying half their body weight. Rock on soldier.

"Retired Coast Guard Capt. Joanne McCaffrey was asked to speak at a Women's Equality Day luncheon held at the academy Friday because of her role in initiating the service's Care of Newborn Children program in 1991, which expanded to today's Temporary Separation Program.

The program allows service members to temporarily leave the Coast Guard for up to two years to pursue growth or other opportunities and then return to active duty.

Feeling "tremendously guilty" that she was the only mom in the Cleveland neighborhood where she lived leaving for work in the morning and that she left the office each day "with all of the lieutenants still there," she wrote a letter asking if she could leave active duty for "a while" with the promise of returning later."

I don't think very much of that.  I have an Airman who was married to another Airman on a 6 manning shop.  The both took maternity leave for the same 6 weeks.  I only had four people in the shop, now I'm down to two.  The place had to be open 0600Hrs to 1800 Hrs.  We had to be there after that or before that if we had a scheduled in or outbound plane.  What the heck would I have done if I had both of them on leave of absence.  You cannot replace them, so you stay shorter until there time is up.  2years is out of the question.

I agree with this comment:

"So....you can join the military. But, if it doesnt meet the demands of your personal life, dont worry. Take some time off. You know, if you have other obligations besides your contractual obligations to the military.
And men, you cant do it. Only for women. Only women have pressing enough obligations.
What a joke.
And then this crap, "we were just as good as the men"
Why do you care?? News flash! Youre not MEN! And no matter how hard you try to make everything equal (by tilting the tables to your agenda) we'll never be equal. Why? Because we're different!
Doesn't mean either is overall better than the other. Just, on average, better or worse at particular things."
Thank you for aserving when you were not wanted. You proved them that you can also serve your country.
Wonderful, you go ladies . I'm proud of all of you.

"More women veterans live in Texas than in any other state and the number keeps getting bigger. Nearly 4000 women get care at the VA hospital in the Texas Medical Center. That number has doubled in recent years and is still climbing.

Young women are the fastest-growing segment of those treated here, and that's why the VA is opening a new Women's Treatment Center.

"We're trying to make it as easy and as fabulous as possible for our female veterans to come to the VA and get great care," said Dr. Rola Elserag, the hospital's program director for women's health.

It may be new, but veterans like these soon-to-be moms are already seeing the difference.

"Since the advent of the women's health clinic it's just easier for us to go in there, and they have people who actually relate to our issues. So it's great, " said Adrian Rideau, an Army veteran and mother of three."
Glad to hear, but all VA's need to expand for women. I don't go to the VA anymore because the women's healthcare is a joke!

I commend the VA for building this great place.  However it's not enough.  You advertise these small gestures and yet the VAMC's in many places are not any better and some even worse.  I'm calling you (VA) out for trying to distract from the many many deeper issues at hand.  I won't forget.  I'm on the front lines.  The battle for Veterans isn't even close to being done :(
The VA systems in California needs lots of improvements, Especially the West LA Facility and the Lancaster, CA clinic which are the worse I think.
Texas, once again at the forefront of things....great story Texans...be proud.
Seattle VA has had a women's center for years. Texas playing catch-up as usual.
ALL vets, including female. vets deserve care.
Tennessee has had one for about 8 years.
We here in north east PA are suppose to have one as well but no sign if it right know.  They have a seperate area for women veterans

"For me, going to Ranger School was never about integrating the military. It was never a quest for fame. It didn‚Äôt start off as a desire to change the perception of women in the military. I really just wanted the same opportunities that my male peers were given automatically."

This is the exact way I felt when I joined the Air Force in 1988 and went int a mostly male career field. I loved being an aircraft electrician/mechanic and I miss it so much. It took several years and lots of tears but when I had finally been accepted as an equal I felt so accomplished!

Bravo Zulu. I wish I had had equal opportunities.  Imagine my shock when I joined the Navy (1975) and found out I couldn't even be sailor! Congress didn't allow women on board ships as crew. Well done! Go far and be proud.

‚ÄúWe had a job to do. We did our job and we went home. We never talked about it. It was OVER. Until 2004, it was over. There were so many painful parts. You just didn‚Äôt talk about the experience. Now, we go to the lighter parts because there are so many parts you will never forget. It is just too painful.

When we left Normandy, we believed we had a bit of Normandy in our hearts. Each year, we have been invited back to La Havre and Picauville. It feels like we are coming home. We return to commemorate the Allied Invasion on D-Day.‚Äù

In October 2012 the Levitsky sisters were among thirteen (and the only female Veterans) awarded the French Legion of Honor Medal for their service to the French Citizens during WWII.
Thank you for your service!  God bless you. You reflect credit on yourselves, all military nurses past and present, and all branches of the military in which we served...a Vietnam AirForce vet.

Thank you. Because of women like you, we won the war and generations of women had opportunities to serve. May God bless you richly for your service.

"It's a prestigious scholarship that goes to only eight people in the country, and one of them is right here in Pensacola. A female veteran is now $10,000 ahead on the way to her engineering degree.

Electrical engineering is a field that some might find intimidating, but as a former Marine, Elizabeth Jones doesn't let her fears get the best of her. Her instructor, Dr. Bhuveneswari Ramachandran, says from day one, she's been a motivated leader and a real go-getter.

Dr. Ramachandran was proud to recommend Elizabeth for the $10,000 scholarship from Google and the Student Veterans of America. She found Elizabeth's determination set her apart from other students."
If some military experience was required b/f a person was admitted to college, we'd have campuses filled with adults, and not the wimpy, sissy, cry babies we read about all the time...IMO.

Ask not what our country can do for us, but rather what can we do for our country!! Little baby step scholarship is better than nothing!! It's a start and additional beside those small Fed grant! Later, they maybe more scholarships...coming from those that said it's not enuf...little by little, the village will grow...if we all pinch in with actions than just words...some billionaire may read this and voluntarily help...
We should be able to award a lot more than 8 of these if we were not so busy pouring billions into Israel and 139 other countries that give us absolutely no ROI.
The sad thing is $10,000 may not pay for a semester at a quality engineering school
Glad to hear she will now be able to continue her education!!!
Congratulations, Women Warriors making us proud. STEM major is a great choice, keeping America competitive.

Congratulations... I received a Marching Band scholarship myself... I heard that the Marching Band Director had scholarships, to increase the size of the band... I ran over and asked for one. He said, "GREAT, what instruments do you play"... I replied, "None"... ..."Ah, young lady can you at LEAST read music"... "No", was my reply... "However, I do have a good ear, and if you tell me once where you want those cymbals to crash,  I can do it... AND I recently got out of the USMC and I march really well"... that afternoon, I began Band rehearsal...
Best wishes, Elizabeth!

"They are in their 80s and 90s now, these women of World War II and Korea, but they jumped to their feet when the color guard headed their way.

Walkers and wheelchairs be damned. These WACs (Army), WAVES (Navy) and Marines stood up for their country. Just like they did decades ago when the country needed them most.

Twenty-five or so of these veterans gathered Friday for a first-time Women of Honor Recognition Ceremony in the Hall of Heroes at Kansas City VA Medical Center.

It didn‚Äôt take long to see that spunk doesn‚Äôt go bad.

Each of the veterans was given a corsage on arrival for Friday‚Äôs ceremony. They were happy and proud. They saw a friend in a stranger‚Äôs face. Later, as family members watched, the names were called and each veteran was recognized for her service with a certificate and pin."

Women warriors are in a league of their own. Thank you for leaving your children,families and loved ones, to fight for us back home. You have my total respect. God bless you, the Lord has a special place in heaven just for you.

I wish my mother Shirley Gresham O'Brien had lived long enough to attend. She grew up in Parkville,  MO, graduated the second Women Marines OCS class at Hunter College  and served in the Marine Corps in WWII stationed in Washington D.C.. She died in 2000 of untreated colon cancer.
These ladies made it so future generations of women could serve their country as well!
The womwn who served during all wars should be honored. God bless all of you.
